The patient is a 43-year-old male presenting with follow-up for ulcerative colitis and fatty liver disease. He has a long-standing history of ulcerative colitis, with the last colonoscopy performed on February 6, 2025, which showed normal mucosa and no polyps, although the bowel preparation was suboptimal. The patient reports no current issues with colitis and maintains regular bowel movements once or twice daily.

The patient also has a history of fatty liver disease, with a fibroscan in March showing mild to moderate fibrosis (F1-F2). He is currently on metformin, which was initially prescribed due to an A1c in the prediabetic range, although he has never been formally diagnosed with diabetes. His A1c has improved to 5.4 with medication and lifestyle changes.

The patient reports experiencing sciatica, with pain starting in the back of the leg about five to six months ago, now extending to the front of the leg with associated numbness in the toes. The symptoms have worsened over the past few days, and he suspects a disc issue.
Informed consent was obtained by everyone present to use ambient listening tool during the visit.
- Fibroscan: March, showed mild to moderate fibrosis (F1-F2)
- Hemoglobin A1c: Improved to 5.4 with medication and lifestyle changes

43-year-old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presenting with follow-up for ulcerative colitis and fatty liver disease. The patient's ulcerative colitis is currently well-managed with mesalamine, and recent colonoscopy findings were normal despite suboptimal bowel preparation. The fatty liver disease shows mild to moderate fibrosis, and the patient is on metformin, which has helped improve his A1c levels.
The patient also reports sciatica symptoms, which have worsened recently, suggesting a possible disc issue.

The patient's ulcerative colitis is currently stable with mesalamine therapy, and no active symptoms are reported. Continue current medication regimen and schedule follow-up colonoscopy in one year due to previous suboptimal bowel preparation.
The patient has mild to moderate fibrosis as per the fibroscan results. Continue metformin for management and consider newer treatments like Wegovy, pending insurance approval.

The patient reports worsening sciatica symptoms, suggesting a possible disc issue. Recommend MRI to assess for disc herniation and consult with a primary care physician for further management. We will obtain back xrays to r/o ankylosis spondylosis.
The patient's A1c has improved to 5.4 with metformin and lifestyle changes. Continue current management and monitor A1c levels regularly.

Karen Adams is a 64 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Recent flare of abdominal pain, bloating and nausea a month ago. She had indigestion, belching and gas. Symptoms were progressive for about 3 days. She did not identify specific triggers for this flare. She resumed her Carafate she keeps at home as she has responded to this in the past. She took this TID then tapered down as symptoms started to improve within 7-8 days. She felt okay up until a week ago when symptoms recurred (belching, bloating and abdominal discomfort). She again resumed the Carafate and noticed improvement.  She takes Nexium 4 days a week and Pepcid 3 times a week, alternating the doses. When symptoms flare, she takes Nexium 40mg once daily. She has nausea but no vomiting. She notes chest heaviness and cough most times at night. She did discuss these symptoms with PCP and Pulmonology. She had PFTs, labs which were all okay. She will be seeing Cardiology next week.

She did recently start a new (generic) bladder medication which she is not currently taking. She does not have her gallbladder. She eats 2-3 meals a day. She has early satiety when symptoms flare. She does feel better once she passes the gas. She has mild constipation during these flares. History of mild postprandial diarrhea at times since her gallbladder. No history of diabetes or thyroid disease. Her last EGD 2022 was reviewed. Colonoscopy is up to date.  She had recent CT imaging to check on splenic aneurysms that appear stable-no records.

Very pleasant 56 YO white female with constant diarrhea attributed to IBS-D. She has had colonoscopy with microscopic colitis. Microscopic colitis resolved with budesonide; but she had return of diarrhea. She has had extensive work-up. CT, labs, stool studies and colonoscopy were negative. Ultimately, we placed her on Viberzi which was life changing for her. She was able to stop lomotil and peptobismol and had been doing well. Unfortunately, the FDA issued a contraindication for Viberzi in patients with h/o CCY. She stopped Viberzi 2/2 this contraindication. She has had return of diarrhea. We tried colestipol, but this was not effective for her. She tried Imodium and Lomotil, and still had 6 BMs per day. Stools were better, but urgency still persisted.

After FDA warning was issued, we discussed the r/b/a to restarting Viberzi. She is s/p CCY and ERCP with sphincterotomy. We repeated Colonoscopy in 2017. This was significant for normal random colon biopsies. She had a small adenoma as well.
She is doing remarkably well on current dose Viberzi.  She is symptomatic if she takes a dose too late.  Never skips a dose.  No rectal bleeding.  She uses Imodium once per week.
She has anemia now.  She had a gastric sleeve and notes more reflux, burping and epigastric pain after eating.  No dysphagia.  +Nausea, but no vomiting.
She is on Xarelto for factor V Leiden and protein s deficiency. No blood clots. This is a contraindication to Lotronex.
In May 2016, she was admitted for symptomatic cholelithiasis with positive IOC. She had CCY and ERCP at THR Alliance. She feels better from an upper GI perspective.
She had bariatric surgery (gastric sleeve) in Sept 2020.Has been diagnosed with rectocele and cystocele.  She had repair in Oct 2021.

She has been struggling with weight and saw Dr. Matin - had UGI with moderate hiatus hernia.  Also noted was a Schatzki ring.  Some epigastric pain and mild dysphagia.  She is on omeprazole.  Pain after eating.

Geraldine Glaviana is a 75 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Status-post EGD and colonoscopy, findings reviewed and discussed. Gastric biopsy revealed erosive gastritis. Tubulovillous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia x 1. She is due for flexible sigmoidoscopy in 1 year. She has a bowel movement daily but it is small amounts that are soft. She takes 1 stool softener nightly. She still has sensation of incomplete defecation. She did not tolerate Linzess. She denies overt GI bleeding, diarrhea, constipation, and lower abdominal pain. She does note some bloating and ""discomfort"" due to bloating. She denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, GERD symptoms, and epigastric pain. She is taking Pantoprazole 40mg once daily. She completed course of Carafate x 3 weeks. Her weight is down 5 pounds since last seen. She lost a total of 15-20 pounds since May 2025. They relate this to poor appetite due to reflux, but reflux is now controlled and she continues to lose weight. She denies allergy to iodine, contrast, and seafood. She denies history of kidney disease. Her father and paternal uncle had colon cancer.

78 yo M here for follow up
8/4/2020 - Saw Dr. Sandoval for colon cancer screening, acute on chronic diarrhea. Stool studies +cyclospora, treated with Bactrim DS x 7 days.

12/14/2021 - Patient presents for evaluation for chronic reflux for > 10 years. He has taken Pantoprazole 20 mg qAM for several years, though has frequent breakthrough symptoms. Rare dysphagia (q 6 months) in mid esophagus when eating french fries. Denies episodes consistent with food impaction.  Additionally, he reports always having epigastric abdominal discomfort that feels like a ""soreness"" but denies specific modifying factors. He expresses concern for possible melena several months ago. He reports chronic diarrhea managed with anti-diarrheal medication. He denies N/V, weight loss, hematochezia, NSAID use. He had a CVA in 2017 with no significant residual deficits. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 2 years ago for which he takes Xarelto. He last saw Dr. Cheirif 2 months ago and reports stable cardiac status. He walks his dog twice daily and denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. He also notes brain pseudoaneurysm which is stable but he is monitored by NSG and vascular. His last EGD was at age 19 at which time he was diagnosed with a duodenal ulcer. Last colonoscopy 10 years ago.

3/9/22- Televisit done via Facetime while I was in my office and he was at his house. reports he has not had any episodes of dysphagia. he had a close episode but in general much better. he also does not have the stomach pain in the morning and sticking to the gerd. he had been on zantac along time then omeprazole 20. now on pantoprazole 40 and appears to be working better. bowels are good. no new issues.

3/8/23- He reports an episode of dysphagia in lower chest with associated epigastric pain once every several months usually precipitated by french fries.  Otherwise he denies difficulty swallowing solids, liquids, or pills.  Upon further questioning, he reports taking pantoprazole 20 mg daily most days and increasing to 40 mg when he has an episode of dysphagia. He did note some improvement following EGD with dilation last year.

6/20/2023 - Approximately 2-3 weeks ago, he noticed an intermittent ""catch"" in his upper esophagus.  He feels like food temporarily catches as well. he denies difficulty swallowing liquids or pills.  He reports AM pyrosis and occasional epigastirc abdominal discomfort but denies nausea, vomiting, melena, or unintentional weight loss.
12/21/23-  reports his symptoms are worse. his GP thinks he may be having sinus drainage he is having to clear his lungs every morning. he recommended a nasal spray- afrin- helps a little bit.
the swallowing is about the same. he feels like he still has some dysphagia. had granola this morning and feels like a piece is stuck.
he did have allergies to grasses and ragweed. here he has strong allergies to cedar pollen. he has adult onset asthma. he did see an allergy doctor. this was a long time ago in his 20s.
has occasional episode where he swallows liquids and he chokes- feels it is going down the wrong hole. happens about every 2 weeks.
reports the famotidine at night really helped him.
he has chronic diarrhea and uses loperamide daily which helps.
9/10/25- reports he is doing much better from the dysphagia standpoint.

he has a bm that is normal then 2 hours later has diarrhea that he can not control- huge amount of water comes out. this happens once a month. eats dairy daily. uses splenda. no other fake sugars. once the diarrhea happens he is done.
stools are otherwise regular. he has noticed stools are less frequent- every other day.
his doctor started a probiotic and psyllium for him.
reports once a month he has solid food dysphagia. overall improved from his stretch in 2022. otherwise does well.occasional meg pain in the am. occasional heartburn
still taking imodium daily for IBS

This return visit is in reference to a recent hospitalization for acute pancreatitis. The patient was discharged on 8/1/2025. Since then, the patient's symptoms/condition have improved. In hospital treatment included IV fluid administration.
Since discharge patient has been doing well quit smoking but has gained weight states he is eating more. Follow-up with PCP has maintained his rosuvastatin. Denies any alarm features.

MRI 7/29/2025 no choledocholithiasis or biliary dilatation. Pancreatic tail edema, concerning for acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis. Correlate with serum lipase and amylase levels. No visible ductal stricture or mass lesion with preserved T1 hyperintense signal. Autoimmune pancreatitis should also be considered given the focal tail involvement. Correlate with serum lipase/amylase levels as well as IgG if necessary. Trace perisplenic free fluid
7/30/2025 autoimmune pancreatitis workup negative patient did have triglycerides of greater than 1500 on arrival and extensive history of smoking.
states cologuard last year normal per patient
Has no quit smoking since discharge 7/31/25

Sharon Hall is a 76 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.  Patient returns for follow visit. She is frustrated with her ongoing symptoms of IBS. Patient notes she was on a cruise in May and had diarrhea most of the trip. She was on fiber as directed by me in the past. She thought this made things worse so she stopped the fiber. After the cruise she was diagnosed with COVID after presenting to her primary care with nasal congestion. Patient felt with not COVID and more like bronchitis. Not withstanding she was placed on Paxlovid which she feels made her symptoms worse. After a week on Paxlovid she was changed to antibiotics. Upper respiratory symptoms improved but her GI symptoms worsened. At this time she resumed fiber which all made the diarrhea worse so she stopped once more. Patient notes she has had a long IBS and has always had problems regulating her bowel movements. At this time she has episodes of fecal incontinence with passage of small pellet-like stools. She has intermittent diarrhea. Other days she will pass just small stool stools that are Bristol stool form scale 1 and does not feel well evacuated. She has not tried any medications lately but feels the Konsyl fiber was not helpful.

BRBPR: ddx of the patient's bleeding includes hemorrhoids, masses, polyps, AVM, ulcers, IBD, or others. Hemorrhoids noted on exam, though perianal lesions also noted. Treat hemorrhoids as below. Pt has hx of proctitis; will obtain colonoscopy as below. CBC and iron panel ordered to rule out anemia. Will obtain fecal calprotectin as below.

Heartburn: Differential diagnosis of the patient's heartburn includes GERD, NERD, Hiatal Hernia, H Pylori, Peptic Ulcer Disease, or others. Obtain H. pylori breath test, then can start omeprazole 20 mg daily. Avoid NSAIDs. Continue efforts at weight loss. We discussed a GERD diet in detail, patient should avoid trigger foods, avoid late meals, and elevate the head of the bed.

External hemorrhoid, perianal skin tag: resolving. We reviewed the pathophysiology, natural history, and manifestations of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Typically, the clot resolved several days following the onset of discomfort, and conservative therapy is typically sufficient for the majority of these cases. Therapy would include fiber supplementation, with avoidance of medications which might contribute to her worsening constipation or diarrhea. Topical analgesics including those with hydrocortisone and lidocaine may be of benefit as well.

Elevated BP reading: noted on exam. Advised pt to check home BP twice daily for 2 weeks and follow up w PCP if consistently >130/80. Recommend low salt diet, regular physical activity, weight loss, and avoidance of caffeine/tobacco.
Follow-up with PCP for elevated blood pressure reading*

Roosevelt Austin is a 80 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Upper endoscopy performed on 8/1/2025 to evaluate recurrent dysphagia revealed segmental mucosal changes characterized by congestion, friability and granularity in the lower third of the esophagus. There is an 8 cm long segment of inflammation. Biopsies were obtained. A 10 mm sessile polyp was again seen in the prepyloric area. Biopsies were taken. The distal esophageal biopsies showed Candida esophagitis. No evidence of Barrett's or malignancy. Prepyloric mass biopsies showed hyperplastic gastric polyp. No evidence of H. pylori. Patient was treated with Diflucan for Candida esophagitis as a cause for dysphagia. He is currently doing well without complaints of dysphagia. CBC performed on 9/9/2025 showed normal hemoglobin hematocrit levels. There were no platelet or white blood cell abnormalities noted.

His metformin was stopped and he started Jardiance and Ozempic about 1 month ago. Since these changes, he has not had an episode. Last episode was 7/20/25.
Regarding GERD, he is currently on Omeprazole 40mg daily. Has frequent breakthrough pyrosis and reflux, sometimes associated with nausea and vomiting. Denies dysphagia, odynophagia.
Also has IBS with chronic loose BMs. Has improved some recently. Has intermittent diffuse abdominal cramping which resolves with BMs.
Denies hematochezia, melena, fever, chills, unintentional weight loss.

column1: Discussed in detail with the patient regarding their colonoscopy results. Discussed in detail with the patient regarding pathology results. Discussed in detail with patient lab results. I have discussed with patient in detail the current diagnosis and differential diagnosis.
- Investigations planned: The next surveillance colonoscopy is scheduled for March 2026, which will be two years after the last procedure.
- Treatment planned: Continue Entyvio infusions every eight weeks.

- Treatment planned: The current regimen of Omeprazole 40 milligrams daily has been effective. Due to the long-term risks associated with proton pump inhibitors, including potential for osteoporosis, impaired calcium, magnesium, and vitamin B12 absorption, and an increased risk of colon infections like Clostridioides difficile, a dose reduction was recommended.
- Medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: Decrease Omeprazole from 40 milligrams to 20 milligrams daily.
- Medications prescribed or discussed, with instructions: Continue Linzess as needed for bowel regularity.
- Assessment: arthralgia, possibly related to inflammatory bowel disease

- Relevant referrals for Issue 4: A referral to a rheumatologist for further assessment will be made if the joint pain is persistent or significant. It was explained that a rheumatologist could provide an opinion, potentially suggest different biologic therapies, or add other medications if a condition like rheumatoid arthritis is diagnosed.

The patient is here for a follow-up on several chronic conditions including ulcerative colitis, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and constipation. The ulcerative colitis is stable on Entyvio, and the next colonoscopy is planned for March 2026. The gastroesophageal reflux disease is well controlled, and we will attempt to wean the Omeprazole dose from 40 milligrams to 20 milligrams daily after discussing the long-term risks of proton pump inhibitor therapy. Constipation is managed with Linzess. A new issue of joint pain was discussed, which may be an extra-intestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease. If this symptom persists or becomes significant, a referral to rheumatology will be arranged for further evaluation and management.

Ruby Monnot is a 82 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
This is a patient we see GERD. Has history of diverticulitis. She is s/p CCY. Also have rheumatoid arthritis. Her last visit was June 2024 with Nancy Lee, NP.

At time of June 2024 visit, she was seen for a hospital follow up at NCB for chest pain. Was seen by cardiology with normal echo and stress test and recommended GI evaluation. Patient had what appeared to be an anaphylactic reaction to GI cocktail that was given in ER. Underwent EGD 5/14/2024 by Dr. Guil with findings of esophageal ring dilated with a 60 French balloon, small hiatal hernia 2 cm. Esophageal bx showed squamous epithelium with reflux changes. Gastritis with bx neg for H pylori.

At time of June 2024 visit patient complained of ongoing bloating and belching. Noted she had discontinued Omeprazole 40mg because she felt ""weird"" with brain fog. She was instead taking Pantoprazole 40mg twice daily without benefit. She noted previously doing well on Baclofen 5mg TID for her belching. Noted she was scheduled for colonoscopy in July for positive fecal occult study done by PCP in April 2024, but she is having episodes of tachycardia and had to cancel the study. She does follow with Dr. Bates for recurrent pericarditis with pericardial effusion, felt to be secondary to her RA.

She called earlier this month reporting a burning sensation in her throat and wanted to speak to clinical staff. When staff called her back she was reporting more issues with abdominal cramping the stools varying from loose to normal. We ordered an abdominal x-ray and advised her to start a fiber supplement. We received a copy of a Barium swallow 8/28/2025: mild tertiary contractions of the distal esophagus likely representing presbyesophagus, mild narrowing of the distal esophagus with 13mm barium pill retained in distal esophagus consistent with mild stenosis, mild silent laryngeal penetration with residual thick barium, recommend further evaluation by speech pathology.
Abdominal xray 9/5/2025: Non-obstructive bowel gas pattern; enteric contrast seen within colonic diverticula noted from recent barium contrast exam

Currently, patient reports is having a lot of gas and belching.  Says she belches probably 75 times 24 hours, says this has been going on for several years now.   States her daughter told her to come off Protonix because ""its bad for her"" and was off it for 5 days and then her food got stuck.  Says the belching did not change when she got off Protonix.  Does drink with straws frequently. Drinks a lot of carbonated beverages and drinks a coke a day.

She has since gone back on her PPI.  Says has not had any isues with swallowing again.  Says food goes down okay. Pills go down okay.  Liquids go down okay. Says no coughing when she drinks liquids.  Says has never had pneumonia. I reviewed her barium swallow results with her and discussed the abnormal findings.  She does not want an EGD and does not want a modified barium swallow with speech pathology at this time. I discussed the risks of aspiration and could cause pneumonia but she says she's never had any issues before and wants to hold off on further assessment at this time.

Reports BMs alternate between constipation and diarrhea.  She did start back on probiotics and that helps.  Takes Miralax as needed.   Says she is taking Metamucil 2 pills daily after we spoke to her about her abdominal xray and she says it is helping her.

Sisnarine Maharaj is a 76 year old male patient who is seen today for an office visit for abdominal pain. Colonoscopy 10/2/2014 noted mild diverticulosis of the left colon and 2 colonic polyps. EGD 10/28/2019 noted nonerosive gastritis with benign biopsies. Colonoscopy 10/5/2024 noted a small adenomatous polyp with no further screening colonoscopies recommended.

Pt reports post-prandial LUQ pain x 3-4 months. The pain is intermittent, sharp, 3-4 times a week, occurs despite dietary discretion, associated with pyrosis and regurgitation, lasts 3-4 minutes, and is alleviated by TUMs or famotidine prn. Pt has been on pantoprazole 40mg q day for several months without improvement in symptoms. Pt denies associated nausea or vomiting. He also denies dysphagia, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, melena, hematochezia. Pt had knee placement surgery in February, and has been using ibuprofen 800mg alternating with meloxicam every other day.

Sisnarine Maharaj is a 76 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit for abdominal pain. Pt has had improvement since starting pantoprazole 40mg BID. Pt no longer reports abdominal pain or pyrosis. However, he does still has regurgitation 2-3 times a week, usually about an hour after eating despite dietary discretion. He does admit to eating late as he gets home a 10pm from his job (uber eats). Pt denies nausea, vomiting, fevers, dysphagia, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, melena, or hematochezia. He is now only using ibuprofen prn.

column1: Sisnarine Maharaj is a pleasant 76-year-old male with a past medical history of GERD, HLD, HTN, diabetes, aortic atherosclerosis, and asthma who presents to clinic for f/u onLUQ pain. We discussed the results of his recent EGD which was normal with benign biopsies. Patient has noted resolution of his abdominal pain and pyrosis since starting pantoprazole 40 mg twice daily, but does continue to experience regurgitation, which I suspect is related to dietary habits. I advised patient that the regurgitation is unlikely to resolve completely on medical therapy alone, and requires strict antireflux measures. Therefore, I again counseled him extensively on antireflux diet and lifestyle. Considering his pyrosis and abdominal pain have subsided and his EGD was benign, I also recommend he trial decreasing back to pantoprazole 40 mg daily and provided him with famotidine to use out as needed for breakthrough symptoms. Patient expressed understanding and agreed with plan

column1: Allan Whatley is seen for follow-up regarding elevated liver enzymes and hepatic cysts.

He reports that blood work last month revealed elevated liver enzymes. An ultrasound was subsequently performed, which demonstrated fatty liver and cysts. He has a history of hepatic cysts noted on imaging as far back as 2017, typically found during evaluations for recurrent kidney stones. He believes his liver enzymes have become more elevated since his cholecystectomy in August 2022. For the past 45 days, he has initiated dietary changes, including eliminating fatty foods and red meat, which has resulted in an 8-pound weight loss. He reports occasional, limited alcohol consumption and denies any illicit drug use. He takes atorvastatin, which was started in December of the previous year. Past surgical history is significant for cholecystectomy and hernia repair. There is a family history of fatty liver disease in his mother. He does not have a history of diabetes.

- Ultrasound of the abdomen on 08/05/2024 showed diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver, a cyst in the left lobe of the liver measuring 3.2 x 3.7 x 3.4 cm, and additional smaller cysts measuring 9 x 7 x 8 mm, all felt to be benign.
- CT scan in October 2022 showed stable appearing areas of decreased attenuation, consistent with cysts. Other CTs in 2017 and 2018 also reportedly showed the cysts.
- Labs on 08/05/2025: WBC 6, Hemoglobin 16, Platelets 225, Sodium 136, Potassium 4.2, Creatinine 1.0, Alkaline Phosphatase 78, ALT 86, AST 50, Total Bilirubin 1.7, Direct Bilirubin 0.3.
- Hepatitis panel in July 2024 was negative.

column1: 1. Elevated Liver Enzymes and Fatty Liver Disease:

- The elevated transaminases are likely secondary to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), though other causes such as autoimmune or metabolic conditions need to be ruled out. The contribution of atorvastatin is also considered. The primary concern is to assess for the presence of hepatic inflammation and fibrosis, which can lead to cirrhosis over time.
- Plan to check blood work to evaluate for autoimmune and metabolic causes of liver disease.
- A FibroScan will be scheduled to assess for liver stiffness and quantify fibrosis. This was explained to Mr. Whatley.
- He is encouraged to continue his current diet and exercise regimen, which is the most effective management for fatty liver disease.
- These are long-standing and have been stable on prior imaging. They are considered benign simple cysts.
- No immediate intervention is required. We will continue to monitor with any future abdominal imaging.
Follow up in approximately 3 months to review the results of the blood work and FibroScan.
This note was created in part by using voice recognition software and was reviewed by the medical provider to ensure accuracy.

Lucy is a very pleasant 68-year-old female with a BMI of 28 that presents to the office today to see me accompanied by her daughter in consultation from Dr. Kapoor with epigastric abdominal pain. Able to review that symptoms have somewhat improved, in mid June 2025 she was seen and evaluated in the emergency department secondary to epigastric abdominal pain. The pain at that time was occurring postprandially regardless of dietary discretion. It was with all things that she ate and drank, she had lost weight secondary to not wanting to eat. She was given a prescription for Nexium which added to the pantoprazole was able to provide the relief that the patient required and she now has only random symptoms that are mild at best. She does have occasional nausea and vomiting but she describes no solid or liquid dysphagia. She is on hemodialysis and this pain has interfered with her scheduled treatments.

column1: 68-year-old female with a BMI of 28 with several months of epigastric abdominal pain and dyspepsia, dyspepsia has resolved. Intermittent epigastric discomfort still occurs with mild nausea without emesis. She does have a history of diabetes which has produced renal failure requiring hemodialysis, unclear if this represents gastroparesis however without vomiting this is certainly more concerning for mucosal-based irritant/etiology such as ulcer disease or mild outlet obstruction. I do recommend she avoid nonsteroidal medicines, continue current therapy with both pantoprazole and Nexium, I recommend proceeding with endoscopy and biopsy. I have discussed the importance of a low residue diet at this time, if nothing is identified and symptoms continue. A gastric emptying scan may be of benefit.

Thank you so much for referring your patient for an initial gastroenterology consultation. History was obtained from the patient and mother. The patient reported experiencing constipation issues for the past month, with symptoms progressively worsening over the last few weeks. The patient experienced a loss of appetite and spent more than 20 to 30 minutes in the restroom at a time. The constipation has been a recurring issue, with periods of improvement followed by relapses. The patient had bowel movements every couple of days, often accompanied by pain and described as small, hard pebbles. The patient also experienced involuntary bowel movements resulting in soiled underwear. Abdominal pain was noted but was not significant. The patient's fluid intake consisted of one bottle of water per day, one soda, and occasional tea. The patient had a limited intake of fruits and vegetables, preferring apples, oranges, green beans, and corn. Pertinent negatives included no significant abdominal distention and no allergies to fruits or vegetables.

column1: 1. Constipation: The patient's symptoms of infrequent bowel movements, hard stools, and soiling of underwear suggest constipation likely due to inadequate fiber and fluid intake. The long-standing nature of symptoms raises the possibility of a chronic underlying issue.

2. Possible thyroid dysfunction: The family history of possible thyroid issues raises the suspicion of a thyroid-related cause of constipation. Thyroid dysfunction can slow gastrointestinal motility, contributing to constipation.

3. Possible celiac disease: Given the family history of gastrointestinal conditions, celiac disease could be a contributory factor. Celiac disease can present with constipation due to malabsorption issues.
- Initiated a bowel regimen with increased fluid intake and dietary fiber.
- Ordered blood work to evaluate thyroid function and screen for celiac disease.
- Scheduled an abdominal X-ray to assess fecal impaction and gas distribution.
- Educated on the importance of daily water and fiber intake.
- Discussed the Bristol stool chart for monitoring bowel movement consistency.
- Planned follow-up after receiving test results to reassess and adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

Travis Sibley is a 32 year old male patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Patient is here for the evaluation of new onset of constipation.

Patient presents for the evaluation of constipation that began approximately three weeks ago. Symptoms started after eating three-day -old BBQ meat, which led to food-poisoning like illness with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He developed constipation and took OTC Dulcolax suppository with moderate relief. Two days later, while in Houston, he ate a burger and symptoms recurred.

He subsequently went to urgent care, where labs were normal and CTAP with contrast showed stool impaction. He was advised to use enemas, stool softeners, and laxatives and was prescribed pantoprazole and ondansetron. He took magnesium citrate, daily enemas, and stool softeners for several days along with pantoprazole and antiemetic, which led to improvement.

Currently, patient reports he has returned to baseline. For the past week, he has had regular bowel movements without difficulty. He denies ongoing nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or constipation. He is only takin gpantoprazole now. He denies overt GI bleeding, weight loss, or other GI alarm symptoms. No prior history of constipation. Family hx negative for GI malignancy or disorders.
Denies chest pain, dyspnea or sob.
Denies smoking or chronic nsaids use. Reports occasional alcohol use.

Anna Perez is a 90 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Ms. Anna Perez presents for evaluation of long-standing constipation that has worsened since her strokes in April. The patient reports difficulty with bowel movements despite the use of stool softeners, which are inconsistent in their effectiveness.

Ms. Perez has tried various treatments for her constipation, including senna, milk of magnesia, Dulcolax, and MiraLax. However, the combination of senna and milk of magnesia proved too strong, resulting in hemorrhoids. Recently, the patient started taking Benefiber and has just begun using MiraLax, though she is uncertain about the proper dosage. The patient denies seeing blood in her stool.

The constipation has been ongoing for many years, with a noticeable increase in severity following her strokes in April. The patient's daughter, who appears to be her caregiver, noticed the issue while the patient was in hospice care. The constipation impacts the patient's daily functioning, as she struggles to have bowel movements even with the use of various medications.
The patient has not had a colonoscopy or CT scan in the past. She also reports having anemia, which may be contributing to her constipation. The patient denies any current use of iron supplements.

column1: Anna Perez, a 90-year-old female with a history of two strokes in April, presents with long-standing constipation that has worsened recently, causing difficulty with bowel movements despite the use of various laxatives. Previous treatments have included senna, milk of magnesia, Dulcolax, and MiraLax, with varying degrees of effectiveness. The combination of osmotic and stimulant laxatives led to explosive diarrhea and hemorrhoids. Recent initiation of Benefiber has not provided sufficient relief. No blood in stool reported. Given the patient's advanced age and history of strokes, careful consideration of treatment options is necessary.
- Start polyethylene glycol 3350 (MiraLax) 1 capful PO daily, adjusting dose as needed
- Use senna as a backup laxative if no bowel movement for 3-4 days
- Order abdominal X-ray to assess extent of constipation and rule out obstruction
- Recommend over-the-counter hemorrhoid cream with multiple ingredients for symptomatic relief as needed
- Consider prescription of low dose Linzess (linaclotide) if current regimen is ineffective
- Follow up after X-ray results or sooner if symptoms worsen

Risks, Benefits, and Alternatives to the procedure were discussed with the patient including but not limited to bleeding, infection, perforation, missed lesions, incomplete exams, injury to internal organs, nausea, shortness of breath, pneumonia, cardiopulmonary events, and other anesthesia-related side effects. 48-year-old female presents to gastroenterology clinic with lifelong history of GI symptoms, worsening in the last 1 year. Symptoms include constipation. She will have a bowel movement once a week with a stimulant laxative. Bowel movements are hard, lumpy/bumpy, pebble-like that are incomplete. She has associated bloating with generalized discomfort. The symptoms worsened in the last year after initiation of GLP 1 for diabetes. 2 months ago, she had diarrhea up to 3 times per day with bright red blood. This was self-limited after 2 days. During that time, she had evaluation for H. pylori which was negative. She had stool studies per patient that was negative for infection. She has never had a colonoscopy previously.

Christian Tuter is a 33 year old male patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Patient previously a patient of Dr. Shahzad and Dr. Chung. Patient presents with ongoing symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and difficulty keeping food down, with a complex gastrointestinal history dating back to 2020. Reports dramatic weight loss from 280 pounds to 130 pounds due to vomiting after every meal. Experiences intractable nausea and vomiting, with water being particularly difficult to keep down. Describes heartburn and reflux with sensation of chest being ""on fire."" Notes that spicy and fatty foods cause severe pain, and high-protein foods worsen symptoms. Mediterranean diet has provided some relief. Despite being on Humira since 2020, which has improved condition more than previous treatments, still experiences flare-ups and reports having black stools, especially when trying to be active. Stress exacerbates condition, and exercise leads to severe reactions described as feeling like ""road rash.""

Previous gallbladder removal in 2020 improved but then worsened symptoms. Most recent EGD/Colonoscopy in 2023.  Also had gastric emptying study and MRI with contrast, both inconclusive. History of anxiety and PTSD but unable to keep oral medications down.

Previously seen by Dr. Shahzad aand Dr. Chung, now here for a second opinion. He has had fairly extensive workup done including EGD, Colonoscopy, US, HIDA, CT scan, GET. HIDA scan with GB EF of 77%, as well as patient reported reproducibility of pain with CCK administration. Underwent CCY in 4/8/21. Improved but symptoms retiurned.

Patient was started on Humira by Rheum for unknown diagnosis. Patient reports his sx improved and was able to stabilize his weight. Patient reports intermittent episodes of dark stools on and off. He is able to tolerate most things but wants to have a diagnosis for his symptoms. DDx: esophageal dysmotility vs gastroparesis vs crohn's disease.
Check labs, EGD/Colonoscopy. Consider HREM in future.

77 yo F with hx of GERD, PUD, and colon polyps here for follow up

4/6/21- reports starting last week she has noticed a little bit of blood on the TP. only happened with a bm after she wiped. this happened for 4 days then the next day she started feeling burning in her lower abdomen with horrible diarrhea- looked yellow then brownish- then the following day had more abdominal pain/burning up to her upper abdomen. also having alot of heartburn. had to take 10 tums to get it to go away. even today she has been having burning in her upper abdomen. she did eat a campisi's pizza before this started that was more spicy then normal. no fevers/chills. has vertigo and can get nausea, can take meclizine and it helps.
has had some heartburn in the past and noticed started in her 60s. would chew rolaids and she would be fine. her mom had a HH and always popped tums. has managed her heartburn with diet.
she has not had another colonoscopy since 2005.

7/28/21- found to have a gastric ulcer. started on pantoprazole BID. this did not help too much so suclralfate was started. the burning sensation has improved along with the the heartburn. she stopped the pantoprazole after the 2 months. she has also started with a stomach ache/burning. also her stools have started with yellow stools/ loose stools. she is now taking generic pepcid and the burning has improved but not completely gone.
OJ is bothering her and so does greasy.
no reflux or burping or severe heartburn.
her last dexa showed osteopenia that was new.

9/22/21- had US abd showing HM, hepatic steatosis, b/l renal cysts.  reports she had her first dose of pfizer vaccine and had a severe reaction at the site. she is not going to get the second dose. she is also not supposed to get the pneumonia vaccine as she had a bad reaction that too. taking the pantoprazole and her stomach is doing well. no further burning in her stomach.
she has not had to take any tums. she has not woken up in the middle of the night either with reflux.
she is claustrophobic and needs an open mri- had prior at SWD

3/24/22- had MRI showing hepatomegaly and mild hepatic steatosis. no gallstones. mild fatty atrophy pancreas. benign kidney cysts. she also weaned down to 20mg ppi. she was in NC from november to feb. she is now back. she has been on pantoprazole 20mg and did fine. she is now doing every other day and then quit. she has been doing well off the meds. if she has eaten a heavy meal or a spicy meal- she will chew some tums- has happened 3 times in 3 months. she reports this is much better then beforehand. she reports she has gained some weight since she has been gone. she has gained 11 lbs since last visit. her liver tests have been normal per patient.

2/20/23-  she has been doing well. she has still ot been doing anything for her reflux. she has had to take rolaids twice since last year. every now and then gets a funny taste at night and drinks water with improvement. she has been trying to watch her diet.
she does have some water retention in her LE and given lasix. she has not used it yet.
she did not really try the metamucil. still has some leakage.
8/16/23- her husband and her bought a home in Stillwater Ok and planning to move up there soon

she has been doing well. she has not had indigestion at all. she has not had to take any anti acids. reports the leakage has improved. she is trying to eat more bulk/fiber. she is not using the supplements still. she has also laid of lattes.
she feels alot better than before.
3/17/25-  reports she is doing well. she reports her stools have been doing good ever since being put on pantoprazole.
she was doing fiber supplements daily and this worked great for her. however she stopped it and now she is having more incontinence.
9/10/25- she continues to have multiple loose bowel movements most days with varying degrees of urgency. She has not been consistently taking fiber.
Her reflux is well controlled with pantoprazole 40 mg daily.  She forgot to take it twice over the summer and had no issues. Denies abdominal pain, melena, hematochezia.
egd 4/2021- LA grade A esophagitis, small hh, 12mm gastric ulcer
colon 2005 with Dr Brooks- no polyps.

Ernest Flores is a 67-year-old male seen today for follow-up. Patient was previously seen for EGD in December 2022. This was notable for hiatal hernia and nondysplastic Barrett's esophagus. He will be due for repeat endoscopy at the end of this year for surveillance. Patient states that over the last 4 weeks or so, he has been having more issues with abdominal pain, bloating/gas, acid reflux and a persistent cough. Patient has also had a couple episodes where he wakes up in the middle of the night and has a sudden urge to vomit. Patient states that his symptoms usually do okay first thing in the morning but seem to get worse throughout the day. He is currently taking pantoprazole once a day in the morning. When his symptoms flareup, he will often take Tums which provides some relief. He denies any recent changes in his diet or routine. No dysphagia or odynophagia. Patient has been evaluated for ongoing cough recently, but he was told that it may also be related to acid reflux. Patient continues to smoke cigarettes on a daily basis. Patient also reports having intermittent loose stools. He has not found any specific foods that trigger it. He typically only has 1-2 bowel movements a day, but it will go back and forth between solid stools and more loose stools. His last colonoscopy in 2019 was normal and he was recommended to repeat in 10 years.

column1: 67-year-old male seen today for follow-up on epigastric pain, acid reflux, and bloating/gas. Patient has history of Barrett's esophagus. He will be due for surveillance EGD later this year. Given his worsening in symptoms at this time, recommended that we proceed with EGD now. Advised him to continue pantoprazole daily. We discussed addition of famotidine to his routine, especially to help with nocturnal symptoms. Patient is agreeable to try famotidine and proceed with EGD. We also discussed some dietary triggers that may be making his bloating, gas, and intermittent diarrhea worse. We discussed trial of low FODMAP diet to see if it helps with any of the symptoms. We also discussed some over-the-counter medications which may help including Beano or Gas-X. Additionally, we will rule out any abnormality such as H. pylori or celiac disease on endoscopy. Patient continues to smoke cigarettes on a daily basis. Reinforced importance of smoking cessation, especially given his history of Barrett's esophagus and increased risk for development of esophageal cancer in patients with history of tobacco use.

Maria Korte is a 67 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit.  This patient was sent by Dr. Sameer Mohiuddin for acid reflux. The patient recently had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. There is a history of a colonoscopy done in Austin in March 2024. It was an Austin GI doctor that referred her for the cholecystectomy.

The patient was last seen in TDDC by Dr. Ilyas Memon in Conroe in March 2019 when the patient was being treated for constipation and reflux. The patient was being given nitroglycerin cream for rectal pain and was on Nexium 20 mg a day for reflux. They said there was a history of colon polyps and had recommended a follow-up colonoscopy in 3 years. There was an EGD and colonoscopy done in March 2018 where there was an adenomatous colon polyp but there was no Barrett's. There was not a biopsy of the stomach looking for intestinal metaplasia or Helicobacter.  In 2018, at least, they did not see a hiatal hernia.

She had an EGD in March 2025 by Dr. Tarkan Dural in the Woodlands. He told her she had a small hiatal hernia. There had been a CT scan earlier in the year that did also show a small hiatal hernia and some diverticulosis. There had even been an MRI in April that showed some liver cyst but no stones. The reason her gallbladder was taken out was because a CCK study showed biliary dyskinesia but did not show stones. Otherwise they would not have done a stimulated gallbladder study.

The EGD in March 2025 showed acid reflux. The patient used to be on Nexium but someone told her to stop it because it might affect her liver which is not true. Part of what was happening was that she was getting attacks of severe epigastric distress, nausea, and dysphagia. She would be eating a solid piece of meat and then she would feel nauseated and feel foam coming back up, have to stop eating, leave the room, and then it may clear in about 20 minutes. This was being called a gallbladder symptom. At the EGD, though, there was a stricture of her distal esophagus that was not dilated. Since her gallbladder surgery, she has continued to have occasional episodes of this discomfort.

She has irritable bowel constipation for years. Before her surgery, she was taking Trulance which she thought made her feel bad and did not really help. She would go 5 days between a bowel movement. Since her surgery, she is having a spontaneous bowel movement about every other day so she is pretty happy about that. She knows she had a colonoscopy but she did not realize it was as far back as 2018 and there has not been another. She was not aware that she had a precancerous adenoma. She really hates the idea of a colonoscopy prep because she threw it all up before, it was an inadequate prep, her blood pressure went up, and she did not ever want to have a colonoscopy again. She has a history of anal fissures and even got Botox injections into the anal sphincter in 2019. However, with the knowledge of having an adenoma, she is willing to go forward with another colonoscopy if we can make the prep easy.

column1: Personal history of adenomatous and serrated colon polyps

Her main symptoms today are symptoms that sound a lot like esophageal meat impactions. I was suspecting that before we were able to come up with the records from her last endoscopy. Indeed, they said took pictures of an esophageal stricture, even mentioned it as a diagnosis. I think she needs an EGD with dilation. We probably should put her back on Nexium every day because reflux could make a stricture more recalcitrant. Initially I was trying to avoid doing another EGD but the records show that she has a stricture and the comments in the endoscopy report from March 2025 mention a stricture. I think we need to do an EGD with dilation because I think that is what is the cause of her symptoms.

She also needs a colonoscopy. She is very reluctant because she had such a rough experience with this in 2018. Hopefully we can make it a little more pleasant by giving her a Gatorade MiraLAX cleanout and maybe magnesium citrate 2 days out. I think it was her inability to finish the prep that led to a bad prep and then enemas and a lot of discomfort. Hopefully we can make this a better experience but she is 7 years out on her colon adenoma and it needs to be rechecked.
She has irritable bowel syndrome constipation. Right now she feels okay with a bowel movement every other day. She does not like Trulance. Hopefully we will not have to think of anything else.

column2: We will do a 2-day cleanout starting with a bottle of magnesium citrate 2 nights before the colonoscopy, then the Gatorade MiraLAX cleanout on the night before the colonoscopy.

column1: Billi Farris is a 47 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

This a 45-year-old female who was sent over by Dr. Mohandas for evaluation of abdominal pain. She tells me that she has had chronic left lower quadrant pain that comes and goes but its been constant now for about 2 months. She says it does not change with eating and does not change with a bowel movement its always there at times it gets real bad and extends down her leg and her leg gets numb. She does have a history of some endometrial thickening on ultrasound and has had a cervical cancer and a conization and she is pending a further GYN evaluation. She tells me that she has regular stools 2-3 times a day with no blood no melena and her weight has been stable. She had a colonoscopy in 2018 with apparently an adenoma and her sister had polyps and she is due for colonoscopy.

The patient has had about 5 years of reflux she was scoped forward apparently 2018 and they just found reflux and reportedly no H. pylori and she has been on omeprazole since that time. She varies between 20 mg and 40 mg and it is better at the 40 mg dose. She says she feels a heartburn almost all day long. She is not having any dysphagia. Her weight has been stable.

At her last visit, colonoscopy was recommended for consistent low quadrant pain does not change with eating or bowel movements patient did have a CT that was unremarkable other pain is more consistent with GYN or nerve issues as pain get worse when she extended her leg. However a colonoscopy was recommended to rule out any GI component. Results are as follows:

Today she reports her pain is inconsistent and occurs when she is having constipation. She does now realize she was taking her dicyclomine wrong, only taking this once instead for TID as recommended. She now has run out. She feels without the medication her abdominal pain with constipation is more intense. She does continue to cycle with constipation with no stool for a few days then loose stools every 3-4 days (with 3-4 each day).. She does feel dicyclomine makes her stools regular and her abdominal pain subside.. She has tried fiber supplementation and gluten free and she feels this is marginally helpful. No melena or hematochezia.

Additionally, at her last visit she was switched from omeprazole to pantoprazole 40 mg daily for GERD symptoms. Today she reports this is working well for her symptoms, only symptomatic once a week with greasy food. No dysphagia.
At her last visit her GERD was stable with pantoprazole daily. Today she reports she continues with this therapy and is asymptomatic. No dysphagia.

Additionally, at her last visit we did discuss and encourage a bowel regimen to fix constipation. She was unsure if she wanted to proceed with this, first wanting to try dicyclomine 3 times daily to manage her LLQ abdominal discomfort. Today she reports she did use the dicyclomine and found this helpful. She is now taking this every 4-6 hours if she has pain. She did not try the bowel regimen and is now having a bowel movement daily that is pebbles to soft and formed. No melena or hematochezia.
Last office visit 6/7/2024. Weight was 182.2 and now 186#.
Patient has a history of reflux. Reportedly endoscopy completed 2018.

Patient reports pantoprazole 40 mg works well to control symptoms. Denies any frequent breakthrough indigestion, heartburn or difficulty swallowing. Pt reports that she recently ran out but few months before, she was having breakthrough acid once a week. It would happen in morning and if she was bending over a lot. Eats at 5:30pm last meal. Reclines at 11pm. Caffeine 2 cans of Mountain Dew or Coke most days. She admits she has gained wt and she thinks this is contributing.
As far as bowel habitspatient reports that she takes dicyclomine BID for cramping. She has 2-3 BMs a day. Rare constipation. She gets cramping if she comes off dicyclomine.
Last colonoscopy September 2023. She has a personal history of colon polyps and also father with colon polyp history.

column1: Dysphagia resolved after esophageal dilation in April
This is a non-billed telemedicine visit, rating specifically to discuss recent abnormal MRI.

I last saw the patient back in April. She was coming in at that time for dysphagia and family history of colon cancer. EGD revealed a small paraesophageal hernia. Her Nissen fundoplication look good. Empiric dilation was done to 54 French. Colonoscopy was normal.

Since the patient was in for endoscopy, she was found to have a mass lesion on the right kidney. This measures 2.3 cm in size. She has seen 2 urologist about this, and it sounds like it is felt to most likely be renal cell carcinoma. She has surgery planned for November 6. The plan is to remove one third of the kidney but if there is significant bleeding or other complication she may need to have complete nephrectomy.

Patient has been requested to have her pancreas evaluated, if possible before surgery. She has seen her established surgeon Dr. Bayouth and he referred her here for EUS. Of interest, Dr. Bayouth's father was her physician in Lubbock.
At this time patient reports doing well. She denies any jaundice, severe abdominal pain. Her dysphagia is totally resolved after dilation. She is not aware of any significant pancreas history.
- Reason for consultation: Follow-up on MRI findings of a pancreatic cyst, referred by Dr. Bayouth.
- History of presenting complaint: MRI revealed a 6 mm pancreatic cyst. The purpose of this follow-up is to determine the need for monitoring.

- Past medical and surgical history: History of reflux surgery. History of esophageal dilation in 04/2025 with good improvement in swallowing. History of cholecystectomy in 1990. Scheduled for partial right nephrectomy on 11/06/2025 for a kidney lesion.
- Social history: Has an upcoming cruise planned.

I have recommended endoscopic ultrasound for most definitive assessment, particularly in light of upcoming planned nephrectomy for suspected renal cell carcinoma. I discussed the procedure at length today with the patient including risks, benefits, limitations, alternatives, and she is in agreement and ready to proceed. She is not taking any medications other than estrogen.

Vicki Gourd is a 71 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Patient was hospitalized in 5/2020 at MH NW for chest pain, hypertension, had a negative cardiac workup. While in hospital, she had AST 28 and ALT 34, alk phos 180, TBili 2.1. She was told she had Gilbert's syndrome and to follow up in GI clinic. Patient states that she has had mildly abnormal liver enzymes for the past 18 years. She has a hx CCY in 2002. She has intermittent mild RUQ pain, not related to meals. No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, bloody or dark stools, jaundice. No hx of viral hepatitis. Does not drink alcohol regularly. No prior EGD or colonoscopy. She has occasional heartburn about twice a week for which she takes antacids prn.

7/22/20: Labs from 6/22 with TBili 2.2, Alk phos 177. ANA, ASMA, AMA were negative. US shows normal appearing liver, surgically absent gallbladder, CBD 4 mm. EGD 7/16 normal. Colonoscopy 7/16 with 8 small TAs removed, small internal hemorrhoids. Heartburn is well controlled on pantoprazole 40 mg once daily. Denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation.
10/13/20: Labs from 8/11 with TBili 1.9 (indirect 1.5). Alk phos 255, GGT 244. Overall feeling well. Has no complaints today.
11/10/20: MRCP 10/26 normal with no evidence of biliary dilation. Labs from 11/3 with TBili 1.5 (indirect 1.3), alk phos 217. Overall feeling great. No abdominal pain.

3/10/21: Labs from 3/3 with TBili 1.9 (indirect 1.6). Alk phos level has normalized. Doing well. Has very infrequent RUQ discomfort, occasional postprandial bloating. Feels like this is due to her diet being worse lately. Heartburn is controlled with pantoprazole 40 mg once daily.

8/7/23: Last seen in 2021. Most recent labs in 6/2023 with AST 64, ALT 79, alk phos 341, TBili 1.4 (indirect 1.2). GGT 332. She was instructed to stop her atorvastatin a few months ago. Has not lost any weight since her last clinic visit 2 years ago. Heartburn remains well controlled on pantoprazole 40 mg once daily.

11/7/23: Liver biopsy 8/2023 with mild macrosteatosis, minimal nonspecific lobular inflammation, no fibrosis. Colonoscopy 10/2023 with 2 cm submucosal nodule in the distal sigmoid colon, did not indent well upon probing with biopsy forceps (negative pillow sign), bx with focal active inflammation and edema.

4/15/24: Labs 11/2023 with AST 49, ALT 83, alk hos 344, TBili 1.6 (direct bili 0.3). Rectal EUS 12/2023 with 20 mm lipoma in rectosigmoid colon. She had repeat labs done last week which showed AST 31, ALT 33, Alk Phos 238, TBili 1.6. She has lost about 10 lbs since 1/2024.
11/12/24: Labs 11/2024 with AST 29, ALT 36, Alk Phos 266, TBili 1.7. Lost about 6 lbs from last clinic visit in 4/2024. Doing well. No new complaints.

12/11/24: Labs 12/2024 with AST 99, ALT 196, Alk Phos 406, Tbili 1.6 (DBili 0.3). She was instructed by his cardiologist to stop her atorvastatin last month. No recent antibiotics. Denies herbals, supplements. Denies tylenol use. No abdominal pain. No jaundice. Denies any recent illness.
12/31/24: Repeat labs 12/20/24 with AST 42, ALT 72, Alk Phos 332, GGT 513, TBili 1.4. Overall doing well. No new complaints.
3/27/25: Labs 3/2025 with AST 18, ALT 14, Alk Phos 145, TBili 2.1 (DBili 0.4). Now back on statin. Has no new complaints. Has had some irregular bowel habits, sometimes constipated.
6/19/25: Labs 4/2025 with TBili 1.4, rest of LFTs normal. She was diagnosed with Afib in 3/2025, now on xarelto. Still using metamucil. Having regular BMs. No bloody or dark stools.

9/9/25: Since last clinic visit, she has been taking metamucil on/off. She gets more constipated whenever she forgets to take it. She also started having more diarrhea for the past 3 weeks. She had a few days of over 10 BMs/day. Last week, she had some dark stools but this has resolved. She went to an urgent care last was prescribed an antibiotics but did not notice an improvement. She then saw Dr. Lugo and had stool studies ordered. She was switched to a different antibiiotic. She is feeling better. Has had only 1 BM today so far.

Patient last seen March 26, 2025 for diffuse abdominal pain and diarrhea. At that time he was started on a trial of Endomune probiotics and stool kit was ordered. Stool kit returned negative for infectious etiologies and patient noticed significant improvement on the Endomune probiotics. He states that he continued Endomune for a period of 3 months and that they did seem to help but despite remaining on them the loose stools returned. He says that recently he has been having up to 8-10 bowel movements a day. He is not having severe pain like he was before. No fevers or blood in the stools. No weight loss. His stools are Bristol stool scale 6. He is having urgency but no incontinence as long as he is near a bathroom. No food triggers. He has not tried any antidiarrheals. He recently started back on the probiotics 2 weeks ago but has not had any significant difference. He notes gas and bloating. Recently he has had to wake up occasionally in the middle the night to have a bowel movement. No new medications. No antibiotics. No sick contacts. No foreign travel. He is taking Metamucil but does not seem to be helping. Occasionally he will have some floating stools but no oily or greasy stools.

column1: Patient appears to be having a flareup in his IBS-D. He was tested for infectious etiologies back in March during a similar episode of diarrhea and came back negative. He did improve at that time with probiotics. Despite reinitiation of the probiotics he still having 8-10 bowel movements a day. Symptoms seem to be consistent with IBS-D. Offered him a trial of Xifaxan versus Viberzi. Patient would like to do the trial of Xifaxan first. If no response will repeat stool studies and then consider switch to Viberzi. If still no response will need to repeat colonoscopy to evaluate for possible microscopic colitis. See full plan below.

column2: Xifaxan 550 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth three times a day for 14 days

column1: Patient to contact us in 2 weeks to update us on his status after completing Xifaxan
Linda Hall is a 76 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

She reports she continues to eat foods with mild dysphagia. Denies having any significant trouble swallowing. Admits it is difficult to know if she needs to have another dilation. Prior dilation was in October 2022 and performed savory dilation of the proximal esophageal stricture up to 45 French. She does have Barrett's in the lower esophagus, confirmed by biopsies, no dysplasia. Denies having any chest pain, nausea, vomiting, weight loss. She admits she is avoiding spicy foods, coffee, and eating within 3 to 4 hours of bedtime, which she admits is a little challenging but this is helped her manage her GERD and dysphagia. Admits she never had GERD symptoms but due to the esophageal stricture, history of Barrett's esophagus, we know she has silent GERD. She is staying active.

She has noticed in the last few weeks has been having dysphagia with rice and bread. Last EGD was on 4/19/2023 which showed T known upper esophageal stricture and had dilation of 40-45 French. Also had known lower third of esophagus Barrett's esophagus and moderate hiatal hernia. She continues to take her PPI twice daily.

At her last visit, an EGD with dilation was recommended for previous findings of esophageal stricture. It was likely needed every 3 to 6 months in order to prevent food impaction and dysphagia. It was recommended she take PPIs twice daily and avoid NSAIDs. Results of her previous EGD are as follows:
8/16/2023: EGD: Normal duodenum, mucosa suggestive of Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia, gastritis, stricture in the lower third of the esophagus dilated. No pathology.

Today she reports she is having dysphagia with non coated pills and meats. She feels these are sluggish despite small well chewed bites. No issues with liquids. No choking or coughing. Previous dilation is helpful.
She continues to take Pantoprazole BID with no GERD symptoms. She does avoid late night eating. She does sleep elevated.

Patient is here to discuss dysphagia. Last office visit 1/10/2024 patient was seen for dysphagia, esophageal stenosis and Barrett's without dysplasia GERD.  EGD 2/8/2024 positive for esophageal candidiasis. Stenosis upper third of esophagus status post dilation. Medium sized hiatal hernia. Pathology positive for candidiasis negative for intestinal metaplasia.
Patient was treated with fluconazole 200 mg 2 tablets by mouth day 1 then 1 by mouth every day for 14 days.  She had been on antibiotics and Orencia.

The patient is seen for evaluation of dysphagia which started 3 months ago.  Difficulty with swallowing has occurred intermittently with solids. Symptoms have been progressive with time. Food seems to get stuck in the suprasternal area. Dysphagia occurs at least once daily. Associated complaints include epigastric pain. Conditions relevant to this patient's dysphagia include known esophageal stricture, hiatal hernia and Barrett's esophagus. Prior treatment has included acid suppressing medication and dietary modification. To this point the patient has had recent EGD with dilation to evaluate this problem.

+++9/9/2025 Stephenson f/u: Pt presents for annual visit. He has been having EGDs with dilation every 6-8 weeks since mid 2024 and prior to that she was having EGDs 1-2 times a year. Her next EGD is scheduled 109/2025. She says that dysphagia has gradually improved since she has been getting regular dilation.
She has Barrett's esophagus. She takes pantoprazole 40 mg BID. Last EGD with Barrett's surveillance biopsies was 5/2025.

Today she has complaint of incontinence of stool. She says she went to a specialist years ago and she was told she had relaxation of the anal sphincter. She was told to take fiber. She has not been taking any fiber. She regularly has leakage of stool. She has formed BMs that are firm to soft. She does not have diarrhea.

This is a 60-year-old female presenting for a consultation regarding a screening colonoscopy. This is prompted by a recent diagnosis of rectal cancer in one of her sisters. They report their sister, who is three years younger, was recently diagnosed with rectal cancer and underwent a lower anterior resection on 08/21/2025. The sister is currently recovering from surgery and is expected to resume chemotherapy post-recovery. The patient has six living sisters and understands the need for increased surveillance due to this first-degree relative history. They report having an upper endoscopy in 2020 and another one since then due to a sensation of something being stuck, which was reportedly clear. They have never had a colonoscopy before. They are currently taking amitriptyline 25 mg, which is prescribed by their primary care provider for functional chest pain. They report their PCP has been managing this and has been performing EKGs. They were counseled on the potential cardiac side effect of QT prolongation associated with amitriptyline and the importance of regular EKG monitoring. They plan to discuss this with their PCP, Dr. Khan, at their next appointment in October. They deny any current gastrointestinal symptoms.
- A subsequent upper endoscopy for dysphagia, which was reportedly normal.

4/17/2023 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using audio connection. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. Patient has no complaints today, she has been feeling well She still takes amitriptyline 25mg QHS and famotidine 40mg BID with resolution of chest discomfort, abdominal discomfort, and heartburn. Today, she denies abdominal pain, N/V, change in appetite, constipation, diarrhea, black or bloody stools. Patient completed Cologuard last year, which was negative. She has not had EKG done in over 1 year. Recommended repeating EKG. Plan to follow up in one year.

3/1/2022 She is here for follow-up. She reports improvement in chest pain while she is on amitriptyline and reports no side effects. She is also on famotidine twice a day with the control of her symptoms. She has an appointment with her cardiologist next week, I recommended that she get an EKG and fax us the report. We are looking for QT prolongation. She had a Cologuard test done last month with her PCP which was reportedly normal and she will send us a report.

08/10/2021 This is a follow-up. Patient states that her chest pain is completely resolved with amitriptyline 25 mg and she is happy with the results. She denies any side effects particularly constipation. Her last EKG shows normal QT without any prolongation, recommend that she gets an EKG either with her PCP or her cardiologist at least once a year, sooner if there is any change in medication dose. Heartburn is controlled with famotidine twice a day and we will refill the same. I did recommend colon cancer screening, she is somewhat hesitant to get a colonoscopy but she will strongly consider it prior to next visit.

05/06/2021  She is here for routine follow-up. Chest pain symptoms remain controlled with amitriptyline 25 mg dose. She had a recent EKG with cardiologist which she brought in today for review and was unremarkable. She is off the Flovent as instructed but remains on half dose of AcipHex with some associated dysphagia. Denies any typical heartburn or reflux sensation. We discussed possibility of side effects associated with long-term PPI use and she is interested in trying an alternative treatment. I have prescribed twice daily H2 blocker which she may use for the time being. If symptoms worsen will consider returning to PPI use. Recommend continue current dose of amitriptyline. No prior screening colonoscopy in the past which we have discussed in detail today. Patient is hesitant to undergo endoscopy and has a busy schedule. We also discussed the risk and benefits of Cologuard test which she is interested in and will obtain from her PCP. She understands if Cologuard test is positive she will need a diagnostic colonoscopy at that time.

11/30/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using audio connection. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. Patient was started on amitriptyline for atypical reflux symptoms as well as atypical chest pain with a negative GI and cardiac work-up. She notes almost 100% relief from symptoms. She is extremely happy with the outcome. I recommend that she can stop Flovent since there is no evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis on esophageal biopsies. In addition I have also asked her to wean off rabeprazole since she does not have typical symptoms of reflux or evidence of reflux esophagitis on endoscopy. Side effects of amitriptyline including constipation as well as QT prolongation was discussed. Her baseline EKG was within normal limits. I recommended that she obtain an EKG with her cardiologist in 3 months and fax the results to us. Audio time 25 mins.

10/30/2020 She is here for routine follow-up. Discussed most recent EGD findings including abnormal lower esophageal sphincter, Hill grade 2. Mild gastritis, biopsies negative for H. pylori. Normal mucosa throughout esophagus and biopsies not consistent with eosinophilic esophagitis. She remains on Flovent as well as AcipHex. She did not take amitriptyline that was prescribed at her last visit. She did try the sublingual Levsin however did not benefit and discontinued since. Her main symptoms are palpitations which tend to occur in the evenings and intermittent chest tightness. She has had very extensive cardiac work-up including 30 day Holter monitor. She was recently started on 25 mcg Synthroid by an endocrinologist due to newly diagnosed hypothyroidism. She denies any dysphagia, reflux, nausea, vomiting, or altered bowel habits. Discussed trial of TCA given unexplained chest pain, atypical reflux symptoms as well as insomnia. Risks and benefits of medications were discussed. She had a thorough cardiac work-up. If she does remain on this long-term we will consider getting EKG at regular intervals to check for QTc prolongation. I have also offered her esophageal manometry to evaluate for esophageal spasms but she wants to hold off on further testing at this point. If symptoms persistent she wants to proceed we will do esophageal manometry in future.

10/13/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. She called in again requesting an appointment. She was just seen yesterday via an audio appointment. She now reports lower abdominal pain which has started 2 weeks ago and she forgot to mention this yesterday. Pain is dull achy persistent. She denies any altered bowel habits such as diarrhea constipation or rectal bleeding. Denies she continues to have trouble with nutrition states that she has nausea and it hurts when she eats so she reduced her oral intake and apparently has lost some weight as well. She is tried some nutritional supplements but that cause discomfort so she is talking to a friend who is a nutritionist to get supplements. She did try 1 dose of hyoscyamine sublingual for esophageal spasms. States that it has not helped her. She was previously on Zoloft and it was discontinued due to nausea. She was also on clonazepam as needed and she continues to take this which does help. We discussed possibility of irritable bowel syndrome exacerbated by stress and anxiety. I have recommended a short course of a try cyclic antidepressant to see if this would help with the GI component of her pain. Side effects including constipation, sleepiness and dry mouth were discussed. She has an appointment next week for an upper endoscopy to reevaluate for eosinophilic esophagitis and possible repeat biopsies and she plans to keep that appointment. I recommended a colonoscopy when she is able to tolerate prep and her nutritional status improves.

10/12/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using audio connection. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. Since last visit patient has sent multiple electronic messages that she continues to have atypical chest discomfort and palpitations. She notes that she had various cardiac evaluations and was negative. She reports waking up at nighttime with palpitations. She reports past prandial chest tightness and upper abdominal discomfort. She has been on AcipHex with no improvement in symptoms. We have scheduled her for repeat upper endoscopy next week for repeat esophageal biopsies. She did notice that some of her chest tightness symptoms have improved since taking Flovent inhaler for suspected eosinophilic esophagitis. However this does not explain her abdominal symptoms as well as palpitations. She did visit with her primary care physician and is undergoing work-up for thyrotoxicosis as well as hormonal work-up for postmenopausal symptoms. She did have menopause about 9 years ago. With respects to possible esophageal spasms I recommended starting a course of Levsin sublingual as needed and consideration for a barium esophagram after the endoscopy if symptoms persist. Audio 25 mins.

10/07/2020: This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. Patient complains of new onset nausea, dyspepsia, and palpitations x 1 week. She actually went back to the emergency department on Monday,Sugarland Methodist, where she had extensive work-up including angiogram which was reportedly negative. Labs and imaging not available for review however these were within normal limits per patient who seems to be a very good historian. No abdominal imaging was performed per patient. As discussed during her previous visit she still experiences some chest tightness which has been attributed to GERD and recently diagnosed eosinophilic esophagitis. After her last visit she discontinued budesonide capsules and has been using Flovent 2 puffs held in mouth and swallowed twice a day. She was also recently started on Zoloft by her primary care provider approximately 10 days ago for treatment of anxiety. I have informed patient that it is possible that Zoloft could be contributing to her new onset nausea and worsening palpitations however Flovent could cause palpitations as well. She also recently discontinued clonazepam however she was not taking this long-term, only used for 5 to 6 days total. Patient states she cut the Zoloft tablet in half last night and noticed a slight improvement in nausea today. She will continue 25mg dose for now if her PCP is agreeable. At this time her nausea is likely prohibitive of completing colon prep. Recommend Mylanta as needed in addition to aciphex, bland and/or liquid diet as tolerated. We will reschedule EGD alone to sooner available time. Patient is agreeable with this plan of care. Total time spent in evaluation via tele visit was 25 mins.

9/28/20 She is here as a new patient with a diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis. She started noticing chest discomfort and food impactions recently. In fact she went to the emergency room after an episode of food impaction with the chest pain had comprehensive cardiac evaluation. Subsequently she was referred to GI and underwent an upper endoscopy. She brought in reports which revealed the linear furrows and corrugated mucosa suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. Biopsies were taken from GE junction as well as midesophagus with elevated eosinophilic count more than 24 high-power field suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. She was started on AcipHex by her primary care physician and was also started on oral budesonide capsules. She started doing an elimination diet in fact lost quite a bit of weight from it. She does notice some altered bowel habits and abdominal discomfort after eating milk products. She was previously not lactose intolerant. She denies any environmental allergies. She has never had a colonoscopy. We discussed the natural history and treatment options for eosinophilic esophagitis. I have recommended that we stop the oral budesonide and discussed either inhaled Flovent steroid or a liquid viscous budesonide to swallow both of which worked very well for eosinophilic esophagitis. She wants to try the inhaler first and if not consider the liquid budesonide. I recommended repeat EGD with dilation as well as repeat biopsies in 6 weeks time. She also wants to proceed with a screening colonoscopy at the same time. Risks and benefits of the procedures were discussed. In addition I have recommended a referral to an allergist for formal allergy testing. I discussed alternative treatments including a 6 food alimentation diet.

- Due to a first-degree relative (sister) with rectal cancer, a screening colonoscopy is indicated. The patient has no personal history of colon polyps or colon cancer.

- Plan for screening colonoscopy. The procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed, including the need for bowel preparation the day prior and the requirement for a driver. The procedure will be performed on a Friday at the local surgery center. It was explained that if polyps are found, they will be removed during the procedure. If the examination is normal, the recommended interval for repeat colonoscopy is every five years due to the family history.
- The patient has a history of functional chest pain managed with amitriptyline 25 mg, prescribed by their PCP.

- Discussed the potential cardiac side effect of QT prolongation with amitriptyline and the necessity for regular EKG monitoring. The patient will discuss the ongoing management and monitoring of this medication with their PCP. If their PCP is not comfortable managing this, I have offered to take over the prescription, which would require at least annual follow-up visits.
