column1: 1. Dysphagia: The primary concern is dysphagia with occasional need for induced emesis, suggesting a significant esophageal obstruction. The leading differential diagnosis is a Schatzki ring, which is a ring of scar tissue in the lower esophagus, potentially secondary to a hiatal hernia and silent gastroesophageal reflux. The chronicity of symptoms and the need to regurgitate food suggest a tight stenosis. An inflammatory process is also a consideration. Other causes of obstruction are less likely but will be evaluated. An alternative plan involving imaging studies was discussed but an EGD is the preferred initial step to directly visualize and potentially treat the issue.
2. Colon cancer screening: The patient is due for his first screening colonoscopy.

- An Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is planned to evaluate the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, specifically to investigate the cause of his dysphagia. If a stricture or Schatzki ring is found, dilation will be performed at the same time.
- A screening colonoscopy will be performed concurrently with the EGD to evaluate for polyps or other pathology. Any polyps identified will be removed for histopathological evaluation.
- The risks and benefits, preparation, and procedural details were discussed and any questions were answered.
- Follow-up will be determined by the findings of the procedures. The results will be communicated to the patient.
The patient has verbally consented to the use of a virtual scribe.

Suflave 178.7-7.3-0.5 gram Drink 1 bottle by mouth, twice a day, split dose per prep instructions

*   We discussed your symptoms of food getting stuck, which are concerning for a blockage in your esophagus (food pipe). We also discussed that it is time for you to have your first colon cancer screening.
*   The plan is to perform two procedures at the same time: an upper endoscopy (EGD) to look at your esophagus and stomach, and a colonoscopy for colon cancer screening.
*   During the EGD, if we find a narrowing, we will stretch it open to help relieve your swallowing problems. During the colonoscopy, if we find any polyps, we will remove them.
*   You will be sedated for the procedures and will not feel anything. You will need someone to drive you home afterward.

*   The most important part of the preparation is cleaning out your colon the day before. You will be given a kit with a special liquid to drink and detailed instructions. Please follow the diet and drinking instructions exactly as provided.

column1: Cristina is a 40-year-old white female with history of factor V Leiden deficiency complicated by Budd Chiari syndrome with resultant cirrhosis status post TIPS complicated by ascites currently on combination diuretic therapy with furosemide and spironolactone. We reviewed her recent Doppler ultrasound of the liver noting a patent TIPS with no evidence of hepatic mass or ascites. Her renal function remains relatively stable although demonstrates evidence of CKD stage III, likely secondary to her ongoing diuretic therapy. We will continue with this along with her routine surveillance MELD labs (her most recent labs demonstrate a normal bilirubin of 0.6, a normal alkaline phosphatase of 64, and ALT of 22 and a mildly elevated AST of 34, AFP was normal at 1.9 with an INR of 2.0 and PTT of 21.3 on warfarin because of her coagulopathy). We reviewed her ultimate need for liver transplant and discussed possibilities to include a living donor versus deceased donor liver transplant and will continue to keep a close eye on her.

We also discussed her recent diagnosis with celiac disease. We will plan on surveillance celiac antibodies with her next set of labs. I did encourage her to become more strict with her gluten avoidance noting that untreated celiac disease could pose significant issues with malabsorption, reduced bone density, etc.
Recall - Labs to be performed in 6 months.
Complete Blood Count (CBC) with Diff in 6 months
Celiac Ab profile: tTg IgG/IgA, DGP IgG/IgA, total IgA in 6 months
Ultrasound Abdomen Doppler Duplex Complete - 93975 in 6 months

column2: Thank you very much for the chance to talk to Cristina today."

column1: Carlos Mendoza is a 64 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient has previously been seen for colonoscopy in July 2024. This was unremarkable and he was recommended to repeat in 10 years. Patient is now following up for worsening issues with acid reflux as well as unintentional weight loss earlier this year. Patient states that his weight was initially around 200 lbs. He got as low as 175 lbs over a several months. During that time, he was hospitalized 3 different times for issues related to kidney stones, so he is not sure if his weight loss was related to that. Over the last month or so, patient has started to gain some weight back and is currently at 185 on his home scale. Patient denies any abdominal pain however he has continued to experience some burning in his chest. He states that he often feels like his throat is ""hot."" He also reports dysphagia and globus sensation noting that it feels like he ""has a marble stuck in his throat.""  He thought that some of his symptoms may be related to his medications, so he stopped all of them for a few days but did not notice any changes in his symptoms. Patient also struggles with constipation. He states he can go up to a week without a bowel movement at times. When constipation is more severe, he will take stool softeners on an as needed basis which helps.

column1: 64-year-old male seen today for follow-up for recent worsening with burning in his chest as well as episodes of dysphagia and globus sensation. Patient has undergone EGD in the past but it has been nearly 30 years since this has been done. Given recent worsening in symptoms, recommended that we start pantoprazole and proceed with one-time EGD to rule out Barrett's esophagus, eosinophilic esophagitis, erosive esophagitis, large hiatal hernia, H. pylori, gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, etc. Discussed risk, benefits, and alternatives to EGD. Patient is agreeable to proceed at this time. Patient also has unintentional weight loss recently although this may have been related to multiple hospitalizations for kidney stones earlier this year. Overall his weight seems to be coming back up and stabilizing. Will continue to monitor at this time. Reassurance was provided that colonoscopy last year was unremarkable with no signs of colon polyps or other abnormalities. Patient also notes intermittent issues with constipation. Symptoms seem to improve with use of stool softeners. Advised that he consider taking stool softeners or MiraLAX on a daily basis along with adequate hydration and fiber intake to see how symptoms respond.

column2: pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before breakfast

column1: EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235"
Ernest Greenwood is a 68 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit.

Last visit 9/20/24: Mr. Greenwood is a very pleasant 67-year-old male that presents to clinic today for colonoscopy evaluation, as he is overdue for surveillance. Does have extensive history of coronary artery disease and atrial fibrillation, for which he underwent watchman placement and has a pacemaker with defibrillator in place. Has been off of blood thinners for the past month under the direction of cardiologist. Denies other GI complaints. I discussed in detail with the patient the findings of his last colonoscopy and recent endoscopy (during hospitalization). Due to his history and multiple core morbidities, I believe it would be best for him to complete procedure at the hospital, of course with cardiac clearance. I believe it would be best to also undergo repeat endoscopy at that time given history of intestinal metaplasia. He understands the importance of contacting our clinic should he develop any symptoms concerning for more expedited evaluation such as melena, hematochezia, dysphagia, or odynophagia, to name a few.

EGD-Colonoscopy 2/3/25: Mild gastropathy (Chronic gastritis w/ no significant active inflammation, neg H.pylori, neg GIM), Several 6 mm polyps removed from stomach using cold snare (Benign hyperplastic polyp w/ focal active inflammation, neg H.pylori). Normal colonoscopy, small internal hemorrhoids.

Patient presents to clinic today for procedure follow-up. Underwent colonoscopy as he was overdue for screening as well as EGD given history of gastric intestinal metaplasia. Also history of PUD complicated by upper GI bleed requiring blood transfusion last year. Recent EGD with no evidence of PUD or gastric intestinal metaplasia. Colonoscopy unremarkable. Since his procedures, the patient reports feeling well today and denies GI complaints. Reflux currently well-managed with famotidine 40 mg daily. Has abstained from alcohol use for the past 6 months.

column1: Mr. Greenwood Jr is a pleasant 68-year-old male who presents to clinic today for procedure follow-up. I discussed at length and in detail with the patient the findings of his EGD and colonoscopy, for evidence of gastric intestinal metaplasia for PUD. We discussed titrating down on famotidine to the lowest effective dose for management of his reflux. We also reviewed reflux lifestyle and dietary modifications, I do recommend continue abstaining from alcohol use. He verbalized understanding. He endorses a history of anemia, therefore we will request records from his PCP to monitor. Given that he is asymptomatic at today's visit, he would like to follow-up as needed, but understands on presenting for sooner evaluation should he develop any alarm symptoms that we discussed at length today. Time spent in counseling and/or coordination of care (including but not limited to reviewing prior records, arranging further services, communicating further with care providers) was at least 30 minutes with more than 50% of this time spent in face-to-face or direct telecommunication with the patient.
Try to taper Famotidine 40 mg to the lowest effective dose/frequency
My office will obtain records from referring physician

Evelynn Vega is a 36 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. She was referred for further evaluation of long term GERD and diarrhea. She reports having gastritis as a young child and having to take TUMs. She tried pantoprazole with no improvement but Nexium has helped reduce gastritis and heartburn. She does have some break through heartburn on occasion despite PPI, and episodes of dysphagia. She was tried on Famotidine but reacted with itching, nausea, and palpitations. Labs from 07/09/2025 revealed IDA and low Vit D, slightly elevated CRP. She reports a new diagnosis of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome in May.

Since she was in middle school, her bowels have fluctuated between diarrhea and 2-3 days of constipation, but this year she has noted more diarrhea. She denies hematochezia or weight loss. She has no history of EGD/colonoscopy. We discussed proceeding with both procedures for evaluation of symptoms and anemia.

column1: The documentation recorded by the scribe accurately reflects the service I personally performed and decisions made by me."
This is a 52-year-old female patient here for an initial visit to see me for evaluation of diarrhea and changing bowel habits that have been ongoing for approximately one year.

She reports episodes of diarrhea occurring on a weekly basis, often associated with diffuse, cramping abdominal pain that is migratory. The urgency to defecate can be sudden and severe, occurring immediately after or even during meals. She describes nocturnal episodes, with multiple bowel movements between 2 AM and 5 AM. The stool consistency progressively loosens during an episode, starting as formed but painful, then becoming mushy, and ultimately watery, corresponding to Bristol stool types 6 and 7. Between these episodes, she has some days with normal, formed stools. She has not noticed any blood in the stool or on toilet paper but admits she does not inspect the stool closely. There is no report of undigested food in the stool. She has attempted to keep a food diary but has not identified consistent triggers, with symptoms occurring after eating common foods such as rice, tomatoes, and chicken. She denies eating fast food, pizza, or burgers. However, she notes a specific Nigerian beef dish from a restaurant reliably induces severe symptoms.

She also reports constant reflux symptoms, which she describes as a sensation of phlegm in the throat requiring frequent throat clearing. This began after her second child. An ENT evaluation prior to 2017 suggested laryngopharyngeal reflux, not GERD. She reports her uvula feels irritated, as if it has been burned. She was advised to make dietary changes, such as eating only salad and fish without dressing, which she found impractical. No acid-suppressing medications were prescribed at that time.
She is not currently taking any medications. She has tried Flonase and Claritin in the past for her throat symptoms without relief.

Her past medical history is significant for a remote parasitic infection investigation while in college after moving from Africa, which was treated, resolving associated fevers. She denies any history of gastrointestinal issues or abdominal pain prior to the last year. A prior upper endoscopy was performed before 2017 for reflux evaluation, but she is unaware of the findings. There is no history of complications from procedures or anesthesia.

Family history is negative for gastrointestinal diseases. Her husband and daughter do not have similar issues. Social history is negative for tobacco, alcohol, IV drug use, or marijuana use. She has lived in Dallas since moving from Africa.
Oral cavity: The uvula appears irritated.

column1: 1. Chronic diarrhea (R19.7): The primary presenting complaint is chronic, intermittent, and painful diarrhea associated with food intake. The differential diagnosis includes infectious etiologies (parasitic, bacterial), inflammatory bowel disease (such as Crohn's disease, given the abdominal pain and chronicity), and irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea (IBS-D). Given her history of travel, an infectious cause must be ruled out. A colonoscopy is warranted for both diagnostic evaluation of the colonic mucosa and for age-appropriate colorectal cancer screening.

2. Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (K21.9): She reports persistent symptoms of a globus sensation and throat clearing, consistent with LPR. This appears to be triggered by environmental allergens (pollen) rather than acid reflux from the stomach. The physical finding of an irritated uvula supports ongoing inflammation in the pharynx.
- Stool studies will be ordered to evaluate for infectious etiologies, including parasites.

- A colonoscopy will be scheduled to evaluate for inflammatory bowel disease, microscopic colitis, and for colorectal cancer screening. The risks and benefits, preparation, and procedural details were discussed and any questions were answered.
- I am prescribing a trial of an antispasmodic medication to be taken before meals to help reduce abdominal cramping and fecal urgency.

- For laryngopharyngeal reflux symptoms, I recommended a trial of daily Claritin (tablet) in combination with Flonase spray, aimed at the oropharynx, for one month to assess response, particularly during seasonal changes.
- Follow-up will be scheduled after the colonoscopy and stool test results are available to discuss findings and further management.

- We discussed the possibility of using probiotics after the colonoscopy to help restore gut flora. We also discussed that if certain foods are identified as consistent triggers, they should be avoided.
The patient has verbally consented to the use of a virtual scribe.

column1: David Weeks is a 70 year old male patient who is seen today for an initial visit.  70-year-old male with history of left tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma status post radiation XRT and cisplatin therapy with last dose approximately 4 months ago underwent PEG placement back in March surgically done.  He reports chronic dysphagia to liquids and solids.  Dependent on PEG for food intake.  He is able to drink some liquids but coughs. He was evaluated by speech.

Modified Barium Swallow Study (MBSS) revealed oral phase characterized by adequate lingual and labial strength and range of motion for tongue control, bolus preparation and transport. Lip closure was adequate with no labial escape. Bolus prep and mastication was timely and efficient. Lingual motion was brisk for adequate bolus transport. There was no significant oral residue. The swallow was initiated when the head of the bolus entered the vallecula.

Pharyngeal phase characterized by timely initiation of swallow across consistencies. The soft palate elevated for complete of the velopharyngeal port. During pharyngeal swallow, reduced base of tongue retraction, anterior hyoid excursion, laryngeal elevation, and pharyngeal stripping wave resulted in absent epiglottic inversion reduced UES opening with consistent penetration of varying depths during and after the swallow from residue, intermittent aspiration (both symptomatic and silent), and moderate to severe residue at the base of tongue, valleculae, pyriform sinuses, posterior pharyngeal wall, and level of the UES which was reduced with 3-4 spontaneous sequential swallows. Overall, movement of the laryngeal complex was significantly reduced resulting in impaired airway protection with absent epiglottic inversion with reduced pressures to adequately open the UES and allow passage of the bolus. Suspect lymphedema as a significant contributing factor to current deficits and presentation. Compensatory strategies such as supraglottic swallow and chin tuck were ineffective to prevent airway invasion. Effortful swallow was effective at reducing pharyngeal residue.
On esophageal screen, no significant findings were noted. There was, however, a large bony prominence in the cervical spine which appeared to be compressing into the upper esophagus.
Indications: Need for detailed exam, hyperactive gag reflex, inadequate mirror visualization,
Anesthesia: Topical Afrin/Tetracaine solution in bilateral nostril
Flexible Fiberoptic Laryngoscopy: The flexible fiberoptic laryngoscope was passed through the bilateral nostril.

Nasal cavity: Septum midline, turbinates enlarged bilaterally, drainage present none, patient's ostia's remain patent patient had minimal 1-2 polyps noted in right anterior nasal vault next to middle turbinate. It was nonobstructing approximately 4 5 mm. Remainder of his ethmoidal region maxillary frontal and sphenoid area appeared without polyps.
Nasopharynx: adenoids minimal, no obvious eustachian tube orifice obstruction
Oropharynx: Left tonsillar fossa region healing well.
Larynx: Vocal cords have normal appearance bilaterally and full motion bilateral. No mass or lesions. Immediate subglottis clear
Hypopharynx: No pooling of secretions or lesions
The patient tolerated the procedure well.

Patient is a 29-year-old female with past medical history is significant for anxiety and depression who presents to clinic today for evaluation of abdominal pain.

Patient reports a longstanding history of abdominal pain, however has been recently giving her more problems. She originally presented to ED at UT Southwestern for complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. She had CT abdomen and pelvis performed which showed findings of acute gastritis with reactive lymphadenopathy as well as hepatic steatosis. There is also some concern for IUD dislodgment however this was not confirmed. At that time there was no CT imaging evidence of pancreatitis, however her lipase at that time was mildly elevated at 129 and was told that she has pancreatitis. Of note, patient endorses daily marijuana use with an electronic vape pen. She reports that she has been smoking almost daily since she was 19. She admits to frequently drinking alcohol. She does not drink daily, when she does it will be about a glass of wine or 2. She also uses an electronic cigarette regularly.

She was not hospitalized at Baylor Irving for similar symptomology. CT scan continues to show no evidence of pancreatic abnormalities indicating pancreatitis. Upon hospitalization at Baylor, her lipase was 41. No evidence of cholelithiasis on ultrasound. There was mention of semaglutide use during her hospitalization as well. However she also mentions that she was recommended to start Wegovy with her PCP but ultimately decided not to due to her suspected pancreatitis flares. Other labs at that time show WBC 8.9, H&H 11.7/37.1, MCV 94.2, platelet count 267,000, ALP 40, AST 12, ALT 10 and bilirubin 0.4. Her urine did show significantly elevated specific gravity of greater than 1.045, as well as trace ketones. Urine tox screen at that time did show evidence of fentanyl, opiates and THC. Patient denies any drug use, unsure whether patient received pain medications during hospitalization. She was discharged home on sucralfate, pantoprazole and famotidine.

At this time, patient is experiencing mild epigastric abdominal pain as well as nausea. She explains to me that the marijuana typically helps her stomach feel better. Since her hospitalization, she reports on attempting to cut back marijuana and alcohol use. She denies any melena, hematochezia, or change in bowel habits. She is currently only taking pantoprazole 40 mg once daily which has helped with her symptoms.

Patient is a 40-year-old white female new patient establishing care with our office. She reports a 20-year history of loose bowel movements, diarrhea 1-3 episodes after meals, chronic abdominal pain. She states approximately 20 years ago she had imaging of her gallbladder and was told that it with her bowel function was not normal, cholecystectomy was recommended at that time however she states she was young and did not follow through. Patient also had recent hospitalization in December at THR Denton for sepsis related to strep throat and pneumonia.

Patient states that she did not have any imaging of her abdomen at that time, thinks it was only her chest. She reports over the years she has tried multiple things for her symptoms including prebiotic, probiotic, apple cider vinegar, over-the-counter medications with no relief. She reports a typical days she has 6-10 loose bowel movements daily. She reports occasional bright red blood on the toilet paper approximately once a month when straining however no melena, no hematochezia, no rectal pain. Patient reports her abdominal pain is all day every day but is worse after meals. Pain is worse in right upper quadrant and left upper upper quadrant but also occurs daily in the lower abdomen. She reports it as a cramping type pain. Nothing makes the pain better or worse. She states she has seen her GYN in the last several months and they ruled out any GYN cause. She has never had any previous abdominal surgery. She denies any immediate family history of colon cancer however has several aunts and uncles with colon cancer. No family history of IBD, no liver disease, no esophageal or stomach cancer.

We discussed need for further workup on her diarrhea with stool studies to include fecal elastase and fecal calprotectin. Will order CT of her abdomen with contrast to evaluate her gallbladder as well as labs to assess for infection. Patient instructed to continue with her probiotic daily and to consider low FODMAP diet.

column1: Martha is a 73 yo female who had a positive cologuard in April 2025. She was last seen for EGD 02/26//2024. EGD showed a para esophageal hernia from 30-38 cm, mild duodenitis, ulcer in fundus within hernia, nodule at GE junction and pathology indicated no duodenal biopsies, no celiac. H. pylori negative gastritis, esophagitis no EE, no Barrett's or Candida.

She was referred to Dr. Bloemendal for the large hiatal hernia, and in that visit on 6/4/24, advised to undergo further diagnostic studies to evaluate esophageal motility and gastric emptying, which she did. However, she wanted to lose weight, so the surgical intervention was postponed until she had more weight loss. She began tirzepitide in December 2024 with Dr. Childers and will continue the medication until December 2025 as she is now in normal BMI and intentional weight loss in 150 lb range.. She has history of iron deficiency anemia as well.
She had a positive Cologuard in April 2025 and was referred to our office by Dr. Childers for further evaluation.

However, she went to the ER on 8/13/2025 for epigastric abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhea, and underwent CT abd/pelvis which showed moderate hiatal hernia,  colonic diverticulosis with sigmoid colonic wall thickening, likely sequalae of diverticulosis. No significant pericolonic inflammatory stranding to suggest acute diverticulitis. Mild diffuse hepatic steatosis. She was given 10 days of  Augmentin upon d/c from ER.

Last Sunday, she began to have diffuse lower abdominal pain with diarrhea and darker stools. She did not have any upper GI epigastric pain or symptoms. Did not have nausea, vomiting. She felt the stools were darker but were not completely dark melena but were darker in brown color than previously. She felt urgency to defecate. She had an older prescription of 10 days of Augmentin she had in the house left over from a previous sinus infection, so she has been taking these antibiotics and her symptoms are resolving.

Today she denies upper epigastric abdominal pain. She states she has no nausea with this round of lower abdominal pain. She did have some bloating and gas, but with the use of the antibiotics, this has dissipated.
There is no family history of colon cancer.
History of GERD. Denies dysphagia, hematemesis. She takes and pantoprazole and Zantac daily. At times she will take the pantoprazole BID, not daily to keep upper GI symptoms in control.

column1: Positive colorectal cancer screening using Cologuard test

Positive cologuard in April 2025: We will proceed with the diagnostic colonoscopy for evaluation of the positive Cologuard test. I reviewed the data from the pivotal study (N Engl J Med 2014; 370:1287-1297). Specifically, in patients with a positive Cologuard: 4% had colon cancer, 20% had advanced adenomas and 45% had no pathologic findings.

Acute diverticulitis per CT abd/pelvis: She has  diverticulosis complicated by diverticulitis as noted on previous CT scan imaging. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of diverticular disease. We focused our discussion on reducing such complications through a high fiber diet with OTC fiber supplementation along with limiting red meats and continued exercise. Per guidelines, given patient's recent episode of acute diverticulitis she should have a colonoscopy to assess for extent of diverticulosis and presence of persistent inflammation, as well as for additional lesions, including colorectal neoplasia and non-infectious colitis, which can produce similar symptoms. However, this is safest to be done 6 to 8 weeks after his episode to assure resolution of her diverticulitis prior to the procedure. This is in hopes of lowering risk of a potential complication, like perforation.

GERD:  She has typical symptoms of reflux disease. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of GERD. The patient is currently on PPI therapy daily versus BID and with Zantac daily with intermittent uncontrolled symptoms and. We discussed the indications for endoscopic evaluation to evaluate persistent symptoms despite PPI, screen for Barrett's esophagus, and assess for anatomical anomalies which may be contributing to symptoms. Lifestyle modifications and anti-reflux measures regarding GERD were discussed in detail. The long-term safety profile of PPI therapy was also discussed. Will continue to optimize the patients anti-reflux regimen with PPI with H2B as needed with a plan to down titrate to the lowest effective dose and/or change to an H2 Blocker alone for hopeful control of symptoms over time.

column2: Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.

column1: Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Initiate standing orders upon arrival to Endoscopy unit.
